function_call.name: classify_risks
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Requirement for specific arrangements for producing pleasurable experiences in nature-related spaces","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Close contact in congested areas may facilitate the spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate ventilation and air quality may increase the risk of airborne disease transmission.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of natural elements and outdoor exposure may impact mental health and immune function.","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilic design may be misinterpreted or misapplied, leading to ineffective implementation of nature-based elements in architecture.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Inadequate incorporation of nature-based elements in architecture may result in a lack of human-nature connection and reduced well-being for building occupants.","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Failure to consider the cultural and ecological context of natural elements in biophilic design may lead to insensitivity or disconnection with the local environment and community.","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Ambiguity in the definition of ’natural spaces’ and ’biophilic design’ may lead to inconsistent interpretation and implementation.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of clarity in taxonomies of ’nature’ in the frameworks may result in misinterpretation and inappropriate application of biophilic design principles.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Differences in interpretations and frameworks may lead to conflicting design approaches and criteria for biophilic design in practice.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Dependence on ’nature’ for survival leading to potential contamination and spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Negative psychological effects of certain ’nature’ elements , fear of snakes, spiders leading to mental health impacts.","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate understanding of biophilic design principles leading to inefficient integration of ’nature’ in architecture.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"The emotional need for ’nature’ is explained as an inherited affection from the experience of choosing habitats and building dwellings, which can lead to a preference for natural characteristics in modern architectural spaces.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Contact with natural features vegetation and water can generate a quick and positive psychological reaction, reducing negative emotions and fostering recovery from physiological stress and health problems.","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Connecting to the local natural environment through incorporating regional features geomorphology and landscape in buildings could generate the ’sense of place’ and ’sense of community’ and realize personal identity, belonging, and cohesion.","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Focus on human contact with natural systems and processes in the built environment could lead to the spread of contagious diseases through exposure to natural elements.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"The theory of biophilia and the instinctive human need for contact with nature may lead to a greater likelihood of exposure to infectious agents present in natural elements.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Contagious diseases transmission in built environment due to close interactions and shared spaces.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of ventilation and natural light in built environment leading to poor indoor air quality and mental health issues.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Use of snowball method to identify publications may result in biased selection of literature, leading to incomplete understanding of biophilic design.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Selection of limited literature on the development of relevant concepts may lead to a narrow perspective on the emergence of biophilic design.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Limited representation of interdisciplinary knowledge may restrict the applicability of biophilic design to address contagious disease propagation in the built environment.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Potential for transmission of contagious diseases through physical contact with natural elements in biophilic design buildings.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate ventilation and air circulation in biophilic design buildings leading to poor indoor air quality and increased risk of airborne contagions.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of awareness and understanding of biophilic design principles leading to improper implementation and maintenance of natural elements.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Lack of contact with nature in the built environment","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Criticism of ’green-washing’ or ’placebo’ strategies related to nature in architecture","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Lack of understanding of the emotional needs of humans for interactions with the natural environment in the building environment","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilia leading to close contact with infectious organisms or vectors","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Loss of biodiversity leading to environmental imbalance and disease emergence","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Shift in focus of biophilia theory leading to neglect of human-nature relationship","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of access to gardens, parks, or countryside during covid-19 lockdown","category":"Mental health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Concealment of lack of real improvements or effectiveness in ’greening’ of architecture","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Elusive interpretation of the notion of ’nature’ in architectural design","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Climate crises, biodiversity loss, air pollution, and other sustainable challenges","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Limited research on the impact of nature-based design in architecture","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Significant impact of buildings on human health and well-being","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Proximity to water source in construction","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Designing with natural sceneries in suburban villas","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Use of front porches to link houses and nature","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguous definition of ’nature’ in architecture may lead to misunderstandings and debates about its effectiveness.","category":"Behavioral risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Literal greening used as a marketing tool may create false expectations and limited impact on social, economic, and environmental challenges.","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Inadequate consideration of disease transmission in natural design elements could pose a risk to public health in built environments.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of ventilation in the built environment","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Shortages of essential medical resources, including sars-cov-2 testing kits, ventilators, and personal protective equipment","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of preparation for future pandemics","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate funding for scientific research during pandemics","category":"Economic risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Study limitations on small to medium-sized medical equipment for covid-19","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Qualitative comparison of technologies","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"}]}
